node.text:
Lyuba's school was bombed beyond recognition in eastern Ukraine. This is what it looks like now.

Hostilities across the world have devastated young people's access to education, and COVID-19 has made things even worse.

Whether living through peace or conflict, children's right to learn must be protected. 

#NotATarget

node.text:
The public water system in Lebanon is about to collapse.

This is how young people, both Lebanese and Syrian, are working together with UNICEF to keep clean water flowing for all.

#worldwaterweek

node.text:
Stop the killing.
Stop the maiming.
Stop the abductions.
Stop the sexual abuse.
Stop the attacks on schools.
Stop the attacks on hospitals. 
Stop the denial of humanitarian aid.

Children trapped in conflict must be protected now. 

#NotATarget

Nkosi from Zimbabwe, Mitzi from the Philippines, Tahsin from Bangladesh and @GretaThunberg from Sweden are calling for urgent climate action.

In their words, what the world is doing is not enough. The climate crisis is a child rights crisis.

node.title: Greta and young people call for climate action

node.text:
Conversations about COVID-19 vaccines and misinformation can be difficult. Before engaging, take a deep breath and remember you're talking to someone you care about.

Learn more via https://uni.cf/covid-conversations

node.title: How NOT to talk to loved ones about COVID-19 vaccines

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 05, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and indoor.

Photo by UNICEF on September 05, 2021. May be an image of text that says '" UNICEF will always advocate for all girls in Afghanistan to attend primary and secondary school, and go to university if they choose. Hervé Ludovic De Lys, UNICEF Afghanistan Representative unicef for every child'.

node.text:
In recent years, significant strides have been made on increasing girls’ access to education in Afghanistan.

In 2001, barely any girls were enrolled in school. Today, there are almost 4 million.

Women and girls are vital to the future of Afghanistan. Their right to education must be protected.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 05, 2021. May be an image of child.

node.text:
“Only an adult can be a soldier. It cannot be a child," James was kidnapped and used as a soldier for three years in South Sudan. 

During a battle, his leg was badly injured, and he was left for dead. A UN patrol found him and brought him to the capital Juba for treatment. James healed and with help from UNICEF, was reunited with his family and is now doing well at school.

James hopes that peace will soon return to South Sudan. "Without peace, I will not be able to continue studying and my country will not be able to develop.”

We must help children like James achieve their dreams. The use of children in conflict must end now. 

#NotATarget

© UNICEF/UNI284222/Willemot

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 04, 2021. May be an image of horse, tree and nature.

node.text:
"Because there's no school, and I can't visit anyone, I spend a lot of time walking by myself. I also don't know what I want to become in the future."

School closures are making children like 12-year-old Caio in Brazil feel resigned to the lack of control over their futures. We must put children’s mental health at the heart of the COVID-19 response.

In collaboration with @magnumphotos, we explore stories of young people’s pandemic struggles and resilience. 👉 https://uni.cf/generation-covid-brazil

© UNICEF/UNI377385/De Middel/Magnum Photos

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 04, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child, sitting, standing and indoor.

node.text:
Two-year-old Fatima is waiting for a health and nutrition check-up at a UNICEF-supported clinic in Herat, Afghanistan.

Decades of conflict, drought and COVID-19 pose deadly challenges for families across the country. They need help more than ever.

UNICEF continues to scale up life-saving services for children and women in Afghanistan. Find out more by tapping the link in our bio.

© UNICEF/UN0511136/Bidel

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Reopening schools cannot wait. unicef ، for every child'.

node.text: Our message to governments is clear: classroom-based learning must resume as soon as possible.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 03, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child, standing and outdoors.

node.text:
Since a devastating earthquake rocked Haiti, UNICEF has been trucking in safe drinking water, installing water treatment plants and distributing hygiene kits (which include buckets, soap, toilet paper, toothpaste, toothbrushes and face masks).

As the risk of water-borne diseases grows, local authorities must ensure the safety of humanitarian organizations to operate and scale up assistance.

© UNICEF/UN0504693/UN0504692/UN0504686/Rouzier

node.text:
For children, the effects of climate change in countries like Bangladesh where water, sanitation, healthcare and education are inadequate can be deadly.
 
Inaction is not an option, we need governments to urgently reduce emissions and increase investment in climate adaptation.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 02, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child and indoor.

node.text:
Schools have been closed for millions of children globally during the COVID-19 pandemic, leaving students like 12-year-old Caio in Brazil feeling lost, lonely and directionless.    

In collaboration with @magnumphotos, we explore how the COVID-19 pandemic has redefined childhood as we once knew it. 👉 uni.cf/generation-covid-brazil

© UNICEF/UNI377424/De Middel/Magnum Photos

node.text:
Baby Thuraya is receiving her polio vaccine drops at a UNICEF-supported health centre in Herat, Afghanistan.

Through COVID-19 and conflict, UNICEF continues to deliver for children and women.

To scale up life-saving vaccination, nutrition and health services across the country, we need urgent funds. Find out more by tapping the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by UNICEF on September 02, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child, standing and indoor.

node.text:
Seven-year-old Polina was scarred for life after a grenade explosion in eastern Ukraine.

“She had a cardiac arrest,” recalls her mother, Svitlana. "She learned to walk again. She suffered deep wounds on both legs. But she remained alive – this is the most important.”

Along with her grandmother, Polina's uncle and neighbour were killed in the explosion. She and her parents received serious shrapnel wounds.

As families deal with the trauma and tragedy caused by conflict, UNICEF is calling on all sides to urgently step up efforts to protect children.

#NotATarget
